text: The natural immunity you gain after being infected with Covid is good, but vaccine protection is better. Getting vaccinated reinforces your body's defenses and reduces your risk of reinfection.

Covid is here to stay so our control measures must be here to stay too. That includes continuing to test, stopping cases from becoming clusters and outbreaks, and learning more about how to treat long Covid. https://t.co/Knd0Nvde63
Congrats to @WakeGov! Vaccines remain our most powerful tool in the fight against Covid. #WeCanDoThis https://t.co/ESwgzsJfN7

Across the nation, Covid-related deaths have vastly decreased as more people have gotten vaccinated. That doesn‚Äôt mean Covid is no longer a threat. Arkansas has one of the lowest vaccination rates in the nation and hospitalizations and deaths are rising.
Estimated 98-99% of Americans dying from Covid infection are unvaccinated. The best way to prevent more outbreaks is to get vaccinated and follow public health measures. https://t.co/IZXFM0tAYH

Covid transmission and surges won't stop until there is universal access to highly effective Covid vaccines and high levels of coverage. Governments must work with industry to scale up vaccine manufacturing ASAP, especially of mRNA vaccines.

Vaccines are extremely protective, but we can't forget the importance of multiple layers of protection‚Äîespecially for people who aren't vaccinated and who remain vulnerable to Covid. Masks in specific situations, better ventilation, distancing & good hygiene can still save lives.
Perspective: The Delta variant is not the worst wild card the virus that causes Covid can deal us. Microbes outnumber us. We must work together and outsmart them.

Heart inflammation appears to be an extremely rare side effect in younger people post-vaccination, but most patients have responded quickly to treatment and recovered. Getting Covid puts you at a much higher risk of heart problems and other serious long-term effects.
The situation in Africa is deeply concerning. Rapidly rising Covid cases in some countries are straining and overwhelming health care systems. https://t.co/irAaH3nSZ2
New hospitalizations and deaths from Covid don't have to happen. Vaccination almost eliminates the risk that you'll get severely ill from the disease.

In the race of vaccines vs. variants, we've gained the upper hand in the US. But how long will it last? Delta's rise, coupled with relatively low vaccination rates among some groups and communities, could give Covid new opportunities to bounce back.

Young children are less likely to get severely ill from Covid, but can still spread it to others, including unvaccinated family members. Everyone who is unvaccinated, including children, should continue to socially distance and wear masks indoors until they can be vaccinated.

Uganda and other places in Africa are experiencing a dangerous wave of Covid. We must increase vaccine supply faster, much faster than we have, and, in the meantime, communities must mask up, avoid indoor crowds, and take other measures to control spread. https://t.co/6L4U2lkcle

Less than 10,000 diagnosed cases of Covid/day in US in past week - first time in since Feb/March 2020. This is few enough so every one of them can be rapidly interviewed, isolated, source sought, contacts warned. Necessary in order to prevent Delta-variant-driven surge.

"If our vaccination rate was higher, we wouldn't be seeing this."

Places falling behind on vaccinations are at higher risk of further Covid clusters and outbreaks, especially as the Delta variant picks up steam in the US. https://t.co/HQ8NMxOcC1

It's impossible to predict with certainty how Covid will affect you if you get infected. Even people who initially experienced mild symptoms, or none at all, are suffering from health problems months later. Getting vaccinated protects you from an unpredictable disease.

No one wants to spread a disease to someone that could make them seriously ill or kill them. You're much less likely to get infected with Covid AND to spread it to people around you once you're vaccinated.

Infectious diseases will not stop with Covid. We need to break the deadly cycle of panic and neglect and ensure that our public health systems are prepared to handle the next pandemic threat.

Genetic sequencing, combined with skilled epidemiology, can help us fight Covid and prevent the next pandemic. We must invest both in technology and in public health professionals. https://t.co/4D1chYwkjH

Just about everyone who's hospitalized or dying from Covid is unvaccinated. Getting vaccinated saves your immune system the trouble of fighting an unpredictable virus unprepared, and virtually eliminates the risk that you'll become severely ill from it.

The proportion of vaccinated people in some US states is nearly double that of other states. The more people are vaccinated, the lower the risk of Covid clusters and outbreaks. https://t.co/Sy5LFjVS9q
With reduced spread of Covid in almost every part of the US, now is the time to get as many more people vaccinated as quickly as we can‚Äîbefore the virus has a chance to catch back up.
RT @ResolveTSL: We must reach as many people as we can with vaccines‚Äîbefore COVID reaches them. That means expanding access to vaccination‚Ä¶

Covid vaccines don‚Äôt stay in your body. They prime your body to fight the virus, then disappear. But if you get infected, lingering health problems caused by Covid could stay with you for a long time.

People who are only partially vaccinated are only partially protected. In one study, 1 dose of Pfizer vaccine provides only 33 percent protection against developing symptomatic Covid disease caused by the Delta variant, compared to 88 percent effectiveness after both doses.

If you're unvaccinated, don't be lulled into a false sense of security by falling case rates in the US. Covid is still spreading, and variants have made it more contagious. Get vaccinated as soon as you can. https://t.co/Sy5LFjVS9q

A study of 2 million post-Covid patients found that nearly one quarter have sought medical care for long-haul health problems‚Äîincluding many who initially experienced only mild or no symptoms. https://t.co/E6PISM00JL

It's been six months since the first Covid vaccines were administered. High-income countries have administered nearly half of the world's doses. Meanwhile, low-income countries have administered less than half of a percent. This proportion hasn't changed for months. Unacceptable.
The US has reached 600,000 reported deaths from Covid. We must do all we can to prevent even more avoidable death, suffering, and grief, in this country and globally. Every life is a universe.
Places with‚Äã less vaccine coverage face a higher risk of Covid clusters and possibly outbreaks, which will result in continued disruption to society. https://t.co/Sy5LFjVS9q https://t.co/hueIjpTV4c
